articles.headline: Inside the Democratic Schmoozefest, Where Hotel Lobbies Are ‘Prime Territory’
articles.snippet: The real jockeying for power in Chicago this week took place a few miles from the Democratic convention, in the lobbies and bars and hallways of the Four Seasons and Ritz-Carlton hotels.
articles.abstract: The real jockeying for power in Chicago this week took place a few miles from the Democratic convention, in the lobbies and bars and hallways of the Four Seasons and Ritz-Carlton hotels.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were on the prowl all week. The lobbyists, job seekers, influence peddlers, donors and all manner of ultrarich hangers-on at the Democratic National Convention.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Theodore Schleifer

articles.headline: Abortion Rights, on Winning Streak, Face Biggest Test in November
articles.snippet: Ten states have ballot measures to establish a right to abortion in their state constitutions. The pushback has already begun.
articles.abstract: Ten states have ballot measures to establish a right to abortion in their state constitutions. The pushback has already begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ballot measures on abortion rights have succeeded beyond what even their proponents imagined when the United States Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade two years ago.

articles.headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Endorses Trump and Suspends His Independent Bid for President
articles.snippet: Mr. Kennedy said he will remove his name from the ballot in battleground states, so as not to be a spoiler.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kennedy said he will remove his name from the ballot in battleground states, so as not to be a spoiler.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. threw his support behind former President Donald J. Trump on Friday after suspending his troubled independent campaign for president, saying he was withdrawing his name from the ballot in battleground states and that Mr. Trump had “asked to enlist me” in his second administration.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien, Simon J. Levien and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: Why 7-Eleven Is a National Treasure in Japan
articles.snippet: Convenience stores are a part of the country’s culture, meaning that the foreign buyout bid for 7-Eleven, the largest chain, could be a hard sell in Japan.
articles.abstract: Convenience stores are a part of the country’s culture, meaning that the foreign buyout bid for 7-Eleven, the largest chain, could be a hard sell in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Japan, convenience stores are celebrated. Clean and bright, they are stocked with fresh and affordable lunchboxes, steamed buns and stews in the winter. The celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain once called them “the one vice” he couldn’t give up.
articles.byline: By Kiuko Notoya and River Akira Davis

articles.headline: How Elon Musk Got Tangled Up in Blue
articles.snippet: Twitter Blue, a revamped subscription service that let users buy verified badges, was the first big test for the platform’s new owner. It didn’t go well.
articles.abstract: Twitter Blue, a revamped subscription service that let users buy verified badges, was the first big test for the platform’s new owner. It didn’t go well.
articles.lead_paragraph: By Nov. 9, 2022, anxiety was high among the Twitter employees gathered at the company’s San Francisco headquarters. They had spent part of that morning trying to gently explain to their new boss, Elon Musk, that the service they had just launched was dangerous.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Can the G.O.P. Really Become the Party of Workers?
articles.snippet: A new generation of Republicans is learning to love labor. It’s not clear if labor will love them back.
articles.abstract: A new generation of Republicans is learning to love labor. It’s not clear if labor will love them back.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most surprising moment of this year’s Republican National Convention may have come on its first night, when the president of the Teamsters railed in prime time against corporate elites and denounced a “war against labor” by business groups. The gasps from some in the hall were almost audible on television.

articles.headline: New Training and Tougher Rules: How Colleges Are Trying to Tame Gaza Protests
articles.snippet: University officials are spelling out strict codes around protests. They say they are trying to be clear. Others say they are trying to suppress speech.
articles.abstract: University officials are spelling out strict codes around protests. They say they are trying to be clear. Others say they are trying to suppress speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than 10 minutes had passed before Daniel Diermeier, Vanderbilt University’s chancellor, told hundreds of new students what the school would not do.

articles.headline: The DMZ Is an Unhealed Wound for Korea. It’s Also a Source of Great Honey.
articles.snippet: The heavily fortified area separating North and South Korea is home to a biodiverse landscape and is a place of deep meaning for nearby farmers whose bees can fly freely through it.
articles.abstract: The heavily fortified area separating North and South Korea is home to a biodiverse landscape and is a place of deep meaning for nearby farmers whose bees can fly freely through it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cho Seong-hoan’s father liked to say that the honeybees on his farm were lucky. Unlike typical South Koreans, they could cross into North Korea, as he had done before war divided the peninsula.
articles.byline: By Mike Ives, Youmi Kim and Jun Michael Park

articles.headline: How JD Vance Found His Way to the Catholic Church
articles.snippet: In his 30s, the Republican vice-presidential nominee read works on theology, mysticism, and political and moral philosophy. And he discovered his faith.
articles.abstract: In his 30s, the Republican vice-presidential nominee read works on theology, mysticism, and political and moral philosophy. And he discovered his faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his new home in Cincinnati, JD Vance would go to St. Gertrude to meet the friar.

articles.headline: Would a Group Opposed to Police Blow the Whistle on Its Founder?
articles.snippet: The leader of Raheem AI had a plan to hold law enforcement accountable, but his lavish expenditures derailed the organization.
articles.abstract: The leader of Raheem AI had a plan to hold law enforcement accountable, but his lavish expenditures derailed the organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jasmine Banks’s disillusionment started with a credit-card bill.

articles.headline: Israel’s Hunt for the Elusive Leader of Hamas
articles.snippet: Yahya Sinwar’s ability to evade capture or death has denied Israel a military success in a war that began after he planned the Oct. 7 attacks.
articles.abstract: Yahya Sinwar’s ability to evade capture or death has denied Israel a military success in a war that began after he planned the Oct. 7 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, Israeli and American officials thought they had caught a break in the hunt for one of the world’s most wanted men.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Battle-Hardened Poets Fuel a Literary Revival in Ukraine
articles.snippet: With verses that capture the raw emotions of the war and resonate deeply with the population, Ukrainian poets have emerged as some of the country’s most influential voices.
articles.abstract: With verses that capture the raw emotions of the war and resonate deeply with the population, Ukrainian poets have emerged as some of the country’s most influential voices.
articles.lead_paragraph: For several days in March 2022, the battalion of Yaryna Chornohuz, a Ukrainian poet and combat medic, faced fierce attacks from a column of Russian tanks in southeastern Ukraine. Outgunned, the soldiers repelled the first two assaults, but suffered many casualties.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

articles.headline: Soaring Insurance Costs Could ‘End’ Affordable Housing, Developers Warn
articles.snippet: Developers and landlords of subsidized housing, who cannot raise rents or charge more for starter homes, say property insurance increases could put them out of business.
articles.abstract: Developers and landlords of subsidized housing, who cannot raise rents or charge more for starter homes, say property insurance increases could put them out of business.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the poorest Americans, finding an apartment to rent or a home to buy often means tapping into a vast network of nonprofit groups that use public and charitable funds to rehab or build affordable housing. Over the past year, the skyrocketing cost of property insurance has put that network on shaky ground.

articles.headline: Apple Rethinks Its Movie Strategy After a String of Misses
articles.snippet: “Wolfs,” a new film starring George Clooney and Brad Pitt, was going to get a robust theatrical release. But the company is curtailing that plan.
articles.abstract: “Wolfs,” a new film starring George Clooney and Brad Pitt, was going to get a robust theatrical release. But the company is curtailing that plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Apple won a bidding war in 2021 for the rights to make the action comedy “Wolfs” with George Clooney and Brad Pitt, it did so in part because it promised the stars it would put the movie into a large number of movie theaters.

articles.headline: As Kamala Harris Claims Oakland, Berkeley Forgives
articles.snippet: The vice president has virtually erased Berkeley, Calif., her hometown, from her campaign biography. The residents of “the People’s Republic” say they get it.
articles.abstract: The vice president has virtually erased Berkeley, Calif., her hometown, from her campaign biography. The residents of “the People’s Republic” say they get it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.
articles.byline: By Heather Knight and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: Telegram Becomes Free Speech Flashpoint After Founder’s Arrest
articles.snippet: Pavel Durov, the founder of the app, which has more than 900 million users, was taken into custody by the French authorities.
articles.abstract: Pavel Durov, the founder of the app, which has more than 900 million users, was taken into custody by the French authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Telegram, founded in 2013 by the Russian entrepreneur Pavel Durov, has grown into one of the world’s largest online communication tools and is central to everyday life in countries like Russia, Ukraine and India for messaging, getting independent news and exchanging views.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aurelien Breeden

articles.headline: After Attacks, Israel and Hezbollah Swiftly Move to Talk of Containment
articles.snippet: Hezbollah’s long-dreaded retaliation for the killing of a senior commander appeared to be over before it began. But analysts said tensions could yet escalate further.
articles.abstract: Hezbollah’s long-dreaded retaliation for the killing of a senior commander appeared to be over before it began. But analysts said tensions could yet escalate further.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, Israelis have waited in trepidation for a major attack by Hezbollah in retaliation for Israel’s assassination of a senior commander of the Lebanese group in Beirut last month, amid widespread fears that a cross-border escalation could spiral into an all-out regional war.

articles.headline: In a Region on Edge, Israel and Hezbollah Launch Major Attacks on Each Other
articles.snippet: The escalating strikes across the Israel-Lebanon border fueled fears of a bigger conflagration, but both sides signaled that they were de-escalating, for now.
articles.abstract: The escalating strikes across the Israel-Lebanon border fueled fears of a bigger conflagration, but both sides signaled that they were de-escalating, for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid fears of an all-out war between Israel and Hezbollah forces in Lebanon, the two sides on Sunday mounted the biggest round of cross-border strikes since the war in Gaza began, with Israel bombing dozens of sites in a pre-emptive attack, and Hezbollah launching hundreds of rockets and drones.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Euan Ward

articles.headline: Latino Civil Rights Group Demands Inquiry Into Texas Voter Fraud Raids
articles.snippet: The organization said many of those targeted by the raids, conducted by a unit created by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, were Democratic leaders and election volunteers.
articles.abstract: The organization said many of those targeted by the raids, conducted by a unit created by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, were Democratic leaders and election volunteers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Latino civil rights group is asking the Department of Justice to open an investigation into a series of raids conducted on Latino voting activists and political operatives as part of a sprawling voter fraud inquiry by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton.

articles.headline: Why Nippon Steel’s $15 Billion Takeover of U.S. Steel Is in Peril
articles.snippet: The proposed merger of Japanese and American industrial giants, which proponents say would benefit both countries, is ensnared by political and labor opposition.
articles.abstract: The proposed merger of Japanese and American industrial giants, which proponents say would benefit both countries, is ensnared by political and labor opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: When U.S. Steel put itself up for sale in 2023, executives at Nippon Steel in Tokyo saw an opportunity: Buying the American steel maker could help it offset anemic demand in its home country and strengthen its hand in a global business dominated by China.

articles.headline: A Trial Asks: If Grocery Rivals Merge, Do Workers Suffer?
articles.snippet: As Kroger seeks to acquire Albertsons, federal regulators argue that the biggest supermarket combination in history will hurt not only consumers, but workers as well.
articles.abstract: As Kroger seeks to acquire Albertsons, federal regulators argue that the biggest supermarket combination in history will hurt not only consumers, but workers as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in 2015, Leonard De Monte was feeling settled. At 31, he had health insurance and was making a union wage at the Vons grocery store in Woodland Hills, Calif., where he had worked for more than a decade. A familiar face in the bakery section, he knew dozens of frequent shoppers’ orders by heart.

articles.headline: Israel Averts All-Out War With Hezbollah, but Its Regional Conflicts Grind On
articles.snippet: Relief that an eruption of violence across the border between Israel and Lebanon has been contained is tempered by a lack of progress in ending the fighting in Gaza.
articles.abstract: Relief that an eruption of violence across the border between Israel and Lebanon has been contained is tempered by a lack of progress in ending the fighting in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of foreboding, an all-out war between Israel and Hezbollah has been averted, at least for now, as both sides returned on Monday to more contained confrontations along the Israel-Lebanon border.

articles.headline: Disabled Troops Used to Have to Leave the Military. Now Some Compete for Gold.
articles.snippet: The Warrior Games have become a symbol of the military’s changing perceptions about who is fit to serve. Some of the athletes make it to the Paralympics, which start this week in Paris.
articles.abstract: The Warrior Games have become a symbol of the military’s changing perceptions about who is fit to serve. Some of the athletes make it to the Paralympics, which start this week in Paris.
articles.lead_paragraph: Master Sgt. Ivan Morera isn’t used to being in last place. He’s a Green Beret. A relentless competitor. But at the 2024 Warrior Games, with his prosthetic hand hooked into a rowing machine, he was trailing the pack.

articles.headline: Russia Pounds Ukraine With ‘One of the Largest Strikes’ of the War
articles.snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
articles.abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine on Monday, damaging energy facilities and sending residents of Kyiv into basements and subways to seek shelter. President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the assault as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
